meta.title: The Most Dangerous Cars on UK Roads
meta.subtitle: Official DVSA MOT Data Analysis

methodology.description: Analysis of dangerous defects recorded during MOT tests
methodology.dangerous_defects_definition: Defects classified as 'Dangerous' by DVSA - vehicle should not be driven until fixed
methodology.rate_calculation: Number of dangerous defect occurrences / Total MOT tests * 100
methodology.note: A single test can have multiple dangerous defects

category_breakdown.category_name: Seat belts and supplementary restraint systems

top_dangerous_defects.defect_description: tread depth below requirements of 1.6mm
less than 1.5 mm thick
in such a condition that it is seriously weakened
has a tear, caused by separation or partial failure of its structure
tread pattern not visible over the whole tread area when minimum depth required is 1.0mm
has ply or cords exposed
has a bulge, caused by separation or partial failure of its structure
webbing significantly weakened
top_dangerous_defects.category_name: Seat belts and supplementary restraint systems

top_dangerous_defects.defect_description: efficiency less than 50% of the required value
has a lump, caused by separation or partial failure of its structure
all not working
leaking on a hydraulic braking system
ball joint likely to become detached
fractured
emits excessive smoke or vapour likely to obscure the vision of other road users
ball joint worn to the extent there is a serious risk of detachment
pin or bush likely to become detached
fractured
across an axle by more than 50%
seriously damaged

fuel_type_analysis.insight: Diesel vehicles consistently show higher dangerous defect rates than petrol equivalents

age_controlled_analysis.description: Comparing vehicles of the same model year removes age as a confounding factor
